findings.title: OCTD - Transfers Contract's Tokens
findings.description: The contract owner has the authority to claim all the balance of the Dividend Tracker contract after 360 days.

findings.title: ULTW - Transfers Liquidity to Team Wallet
findings.description: The contract owner has the authority to transfer funds without limit to the team wallet.

findings.title: DSM - Data Structure Misuse
findings.description: The contract uses the variable `_alwaysOnNeverOff` as a mapping. The business logic of the contract does not require mapping since only one address is used on the mapping.

findings.title: DDP - Decimal Division Precision
findings.description: Division of decimal (fixed point) numbers can result in rounding errors due to the way that division is implemented in Solidity, leading to issues with precise calculations with decimal numbers.

findings.title: MEM - Missing Error Messages
findings.description: The contract is missing error messages. These missing error messages are making it difficult to identify and fix the issue.

findings.title: EFO - Exclude Function Optimization
findings.description: The `excludeFromDividends` function is re-excluding an address even if it is already included, which can be optimized to reduce size, memory consumption, and execution time.

findings.title: PTRP - Potential Transfer Revert Propagation
findings.description: The contract sends funds to a `addressNFTfarmPool` as part of the transfer flow. This address can either be a wallet address or a contract. If the address belongs to a contract then it may revert from incoming payment. As a result, the error will propagate to the token’s contract and revert the transfer.

findings.title: RSML - Redundant SafeMath Library
findings.description: The usage of the SafeMath library adds complexity and overhead, increasing gas consumption unnecessarily since Solidity versions 0.8.0 and above have native functionality for arithmetic operations that revert to underflow and overflow.

findings.title: RSK - Redundant Storage Keyword
findings.description: The contract uses the `storage` keyword in a view function which is redundant as view functions do not modify the state of the contract and do not perform any actions that cost gas.

findings.title: IDI - Immutable Declaration Improvement
findings.description: The contract is using variables that initialize them only in the constructor and are not mutated by other functions, but these variables are not defined as `immutable`.

findings.title: L02 - State Variables could be Declared Constant
findings.description: State variables can be declared as constant using the constant keyword to ensure their values cannot be changed after being set, which decreases gas consumption of the corresponding transaction.

findings.title: L04 - Conformance to Solidity Naming Conventions
findings.description: The code does not adhere to the Solidity style guide, which can negatively impact readability and maintainability.

findings.title: L05 - Unused State Variable
findings.description: An unused state variable is a state variable that is declared in the contract, but is never used in any of the contract's functions. This can happen if the state variable was originally intended to be used, but was later removed or never used.

findings.title: L07 - Missing Events Arithmetic
findings.description: Events are a way to record and log information about changes or actions that occur within a contract. They are often used to notify external parties or clients about events that have occurred within the contract, such as the transfer of tokens or the completion of a task.

findings.title: L09 - Dead Code Elimination
findings.description: Dead code can make a contract more difficult to understand and maintain, and can also increase the size of the contract and the cost of deploying and interacting with it.

findings.title: L11 - Unnecessary Boolean equality
findings.description: Boolean equality is unnecessary when comparing two boolean values.

findings.title: L12 - Using Variables before Declaration
findings.description: The contract is using a variable before the declaration. This is usually happening either if it has not been declared yet or if the variable has been declared in a different scope.
